Community sensitization campaigns on preventing mosquito breeding and proper waste disposal enhance intervention effectiveness. Ongoing entomological surveillance provides real-time data to adjust control measures and ensures that residual vector populations are addressed, mitigating the risk of vector-borne disease resurgence during the recovery phase.

Vector control measures are critical in areas affected by flooding to prevent disease outbreaks. Accumulation of standing water in urban and rural settings creates breeding habitats for mosquitoes and other vectors. Immediate response actions include identifying high-risk sites, removing unnecessary water containers, and applying larvicides in non-drainable water sources. Distribution of protective tools, such as mosquito nets, and community-based clean-up initiatives support these measures. Regular entomological surveys help detect increases in vector density and guide intervention adjustments. Coordination between health agencies, local authorities, and community groups enhances efficiency and coverage, reducing the risk of transmission of vector-borne illnesses in post-flood environments.

In flood-affected zones, vector management should focus on rapidly identifying and mitigating breeding sites. Standing water within household compounds, roadways, and communal areas requires inspection and treatment. Integrated approaches combining larval control, adult vector suppression, and environmental hygiene interventions are most effective. Public awareness campaigns encourage residents to eliminate potential breeding sites and maintain personal protection measures. Surveillance data collected on vector density and distribution informs prioritization of interventions and ensures efficient allocation of limited resources. Sustained vector control during the post-flood period is essential to prevent the establishment of vector populations capable of initiating disease transmission cycles.

Vector populations can surge in flood-affected areas where stagnant water persists. Rapid assessment of breeding sites, including water-filled containers, debris, and natural depressions, enables prioritization of control measures. Applying larvicides and implementing community-driven clean-up operations reduce vector habitats. Education on protective practices, such as using bed nets and avoiding outdoor exposure during peak biting times, supports technical interventions. Continuous monitoring of vector densities allows health teams to adjust strategies, ensuring that resources are focused on the most vulnerable zones. Coordinated action between emergency response teams, public health authorities, and local communities strengthens overall vector control and reduces the risk of disease transmission during the post-flood period.

Experience from past flood events highlights the importance of early and sustained vector control. Residual pools, clogged drains, and containers serve as prolific breeding grounds for mosquitoes, heightening the risk of dengue, chikungunya, and malaria. Interventions include systematic removal or treatment of stagnant water, targeted larviciding, and promotion of community-led environmental management. Adult vector control measures may complement these efforts in densely populated areas. Ongoing entomological surveillance is essential for detecting trends in vector density and guiding timely adjustments to control strategies. Collaboration among public health teams, local authorities, and residents ensures high coverage and effectiveness of interventions, minimizing the public health impact of vector-borne diseases following flood events.

When reporting a flooded or impassable road, provide the exact location (street name, cross-streets, nearby landmarks), estimated water depth, and any visible hazards such as debris, strong currents, or downed power lines. This initial detail is critical for an effective response.

All citizen reports of road blockages due to flooding must be verified by a designated scout team or through visual confirmation from a reliable source (e.g., traffic cameras, drone footage) before updating the official incident map and routing information for emergency vehicles.

Road status during a flood should be classified using standardized terminology: 'Passable' (safe for all vehicles), 'Passable with Caution' (requires high-clearance or 4x4 vehicles), 'Impassable' (closed to all traffic), or 'Submerged' (condition unknown, avoid).

Crucial Safety Warning: Never drive or walk through floodwaters. As little as 15 cm (6 inches) of moving water can knock you off your feet, and 30 cm (1 foot) can sweep a vehicle away. Turn around, don't drown.

Road clearance operations must prioritize routes that provide access for emergency services to affected areas, lead to hospitals and medical centers, facilitate planned evacuations, and allow for the transport of critical relief supplies like food, water, and medicine.

If a flooded road has downed power lines, report it as a critical electrical hazard. The road must be immediately cordoned off to all personnel. The utility company must be notified to de-energize the lines before any rescue or clearance operations can safely begin.

Post-flood, all bridges, culverts, and roadways that were submerged must undergo a structural integrity assessment by qualified engineers before being reopened to the public. Key signs of damage include foundation scouring, pavement cracking, and erosion of embankments.

Field teams reporting on road conditions must systematically collect data for the Common Operational Picture. Required data points include: GPS coordinates of the obstruction, type of blockage (e.g., water, mudslide, debris), water level, and current accessibility for different vehicle types (e.g., ambulance, truck, standard car).

Establish a direct communication link between the disaster management center and local/national transportation authorities. This ensures road status information and closure updates are shared in real-time for coordinated detour management and consistent public information.

Immediate public alerts for major road closures must be disseminated via multiple channels, including SMS, radio broadcasts, and official social media. The alert must clearly state the road name, affected section, and officially recommended alternative routes.

A mandatory curfew may be imposed in severely flooded areas. During curfew hours, all non-essential civilian movement is strictly prohibited to ensure public safety and to allow unhindered operation of search and rescue teams.

Movement by any means (foot or vehicle) is forbidden in areas where floodwater is rapidly rising or has a visible, strong current. The risk of being swept away is extremely high regardless of water depth.

Access to restricted zones is controlled by checkpoints. Only credentialed personnel, such as emergency responders, verified utility workers, and accredited humanitarian staff, are permitted entry. All others will be turned away.
Avoid all contact with floodwater in areas flagged for chemical or sewage contamination. Movement through these zones is restricted to HAZMAT teams, as exposure can cause severe illness and injury.

A total movement ban is in effect for areas downstream of a compromised dam or levee. This is a no-entry zone due to the imminent risk of catastrophic structural failure. Evacuate immediately if in this zone.

Specific routes may be designated as 'Humanitarian Corridors.' These are restricted to vehicles transporting relief supplies, medical teams, and aid workers to ensure aid can be delivered efficiently. Unauthorized travel on these routes is prohibited.

Movement restrictions do not apply to individuals with a verified, life-threatening medical emergency. Inform authorities at checkpoints about the medical situation to be granted safe passage or to receive immediate assistance.
Entry into areas where floodwaters have receded may remain restricted until officials declare them safe. Hazards such as unstable structures, sinkholes, and downed power lines may still be present.

The use of private boats or personal watercraft for sightseeing or uncoordinated rescue attempts is strictly forbidden. Such activities can interfere with official rescue operations and create dangerous conditions for both rescuers and the public.

Lifting of movement restrictions will be conducted in a phased manner. Official announcements will be made through public channels as specific zones, neighborhoods, or roads are inspected and deemed safe for public access.

Medical evacuation during floods is prioritized using a triage system. Patients with life-threatening injuries or acute, severe medical conditions (e.g., heart attack, major trauma, complicated childbirth) receive the highest priority for immediate transport.

When requesting a medical evacuation, clearly state the patient's exact location, the number of individuals affected, the specific nature of the medical emergency, and the patient's current condition. This information is vital for a rapid and effective response.

Special priority for medical evacuation should be given to vulnerable populations, even if their condition is not critical. This includes infants, pregnant women, the elderly, and persons with disabilities or chronic illnesses requiring continuous care (e.g., dialysis, insulin).

Medical evacuation methods are determined by flood conditions and patient needs. Options include rescue boats for submerged streets, helicopters for inaccessible areas, and high-clearance ambulances for roads with shallow water.

The destination for an evacuated patient must be coordinated with a central medical dispatch. This prevents overcrowding at a single hospital and ensures the patient is transported to a facility that is operational and equipped to handle their specific medical needs.

For evacuating patients dependent on temperature-sensitive medicines like insulin, or when transporting vaccines, maintaining the 'cold chain' is a critical protocol. Use validated cold boxes or containers to prevent spoilage.

Every patient evacuated must be tagged with essential information: name, age, triage category, and initial medical assessment. This ensures continuity of care and helps in tracking patients from the point of rescue to the receiving medical facility.

A medical evacuation must be aborted or delayed if immediate hazards threaten the rescue team, such as strong water currents, risk of structural collapse, or live power lines in the water. Team safety must be secured before proceeding with the rescue.

All communication regarding medical evacuations, including initial requests, team dispatch, and arrival at a hospital, must be routed through the Emergency Operations Center to ensure proper logging, resource allocation, and a common operational picture.

The recovery of deceased persons is not considered a medical evacuation. While important, these operations are a lower priority than rescuing live victims and are conducted by specialized teams to ensure proper handling and identification.

The highest priority for fuel allocation (Tier 1) is for life-saving operations. This includes vehicles for search and rescue, ambulances for medical evacuations, and boats or aircraft involved in accessing isolated victims.

Tier 2 fuel priority is for generators powering critical infrastructure. This includes ensuring continuous power for hospitals, medical clinics, water purification plants, and the primary Emergency Operations Center.

Tier 3 fuel allocation is for the transportation and logistics of distributing essential relief supplies. This covers trucks and other vehicles delivering food, clean water, tents, and medical supplies to affected communities.

Fuel must be allocated for high-capacity water pumps essential for de-watering operations. Priority is given to pumping floodwater out of critical facilities like hospitals, power substations, and key transportation hubs.

All designated fuel depots and mobile tankers must be secured to prevent theft and unauthorized use. Maintain a strict log of all dispensed fuel, noting the receiving unit, vehicle, and authorized purpose.

All fuel requests must be submitted through a formal process to the Logistics Section of the command structure. The request must justify the need against the established priority tiers and be approved before fuel is dispensed.

In the recovery phase, fuel should be prioritized for heavy machinery like excavators and bulldozers for debris and mud clearance. The primary objective is to reopen main access roads and clear routes to critical facilities.

A specific fuel allocation should be reserved for accredited humanitarian partners (e.g., Red Cross/Crescent) to power their vehicles for aid distribution and mobile health clinics, ensuring coordinated relief efforts.

Public Announcement: Due to the emergency, available fuel is being strictly prioritized for rescue and emergency services. Commercial fuel stations may have limited or no supply. We advise all residents to conserve personal fuel.

Ensure uninterrupted fuel supply to hospital backup generators. This is a critical priority to maintain power for life-support systems, operating theaters, and cold storage for medicines and blood products.

The primary priority for debris clearance is to clear major transportation routes. This includes roads leading to hospitals, emergency operation centers, airports, and areas required for the delivery of humanitarian aid.

Before commencing any debris clearance, a safety assessment of the area is mandatory. Check for immediate hazards such as downed power lines, gas leaks, unstable building structures, and the presence of hazardous materials.

Debris must be segregated at the collection point. Create separate piles for different types of waste: 1) vegetative debris (trees, plants), 2) construction and demolition materials, 3) household appliances, and 4) hazardous waste.

Any material contaminated with floodwater may contain sewage or chemicals. Personnel involved in debris clearance must wear appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), including gloves, waterproof boots, and safety glasses.

Public Notice: Residents should place flood debris on the curb for collection. Do not block the roadway, sidewalks, or storm drains. Separating your debris into different piles (e.g., green waste, construction) will speed up the collection process.

The removal and disposal of animal carcasses is a public health priority to prevent the spread of vector-borne diseases. This task must be handled by designated public health or veterinary teams following strict safety protocols.

A critical step in flood recovery is clearing debris from rivers, streams, and drainage channels. This helps restore natural water flow and mitigates the risk of future flooding in the event of more rainfall.

The use of heavy machinery for debris removal requires a certified operator and a spotter on the ground. The spotter's role is to guide the operator and ensure the safety of other workers and the public in the vicinity.

Establish Temporary Debris Staging Sites (TDSS) in safe, pre-approved locations. These sites are used to sort and temporarily store debris before it is transported to a final disposal site, such as a landfill or recycling center.

Accurate documentation of debris removal is essential. Record the volume (in cubic meters), type of debris, location, and resources used (man-hours, equipment hours). This data is vital for project management and financial claims.

Site selection for relief delivery points is critical. The location must be on high ground, safe from potential flooding, easily accessible by supply vehicles, and central to the affected population. Use public buildings like schools or community centers where possible.

The locations, operating hours, and types of aid available at official relief delivery points must be clearly communicated to the affected population. Use all available channels, including radio, SMS, social media, and community leaders.

Implement effective crowd management at all delivery points to ensure a safe and orderly distribution process. This includes setting up clear queuing lines, providing shade and water for those waiting, and ensuring a secure environment.

Establish a separate or prioritized distribution line for highly vulnerable groups. This includes pregnant or lactating women, the elderly, persons with disabilities, and families with infants, to ensure they receive aid without long waits or safety risks.

To prevent disease outbreaks, all relief distribution points must be equipped with basic hygiene facilities. This includes access to clean water, hand-washing stations with soap, and gender-segregated toilets.

Each delivery point must have a clearly defined team structure. Key roles include a site manager, registration staff, distributors, crowd control personnel, and a designated person to handle complaints or feedback from the community.

Maintain a strict inventory management system at each delivery point. Use stock cards or a digital system to track all incoming and outgoing relief items. This prevents loss, ensures accountability, and informs future supply needs.

Establish a simple, visible, and accessible feedback and complaints desk at every distribution point. This ensures that the response is accountable to the affected population and can adapt to their stated needs.

Relief items should be distributed based on verified needs from initial rapid assessments. A standard relief package often includes food, water purification tablets, hygiene kits, blankets, and basic cooking utensils.

The closure of a relief delivery point must be planned and communicated to the community in advance. Ensure a smooth transition to other forms of aid, such as cash assistance or local market recovery, as the situation stabilizes.

During registration and needs assessments, proactively identify individuals who require accessible transport. This includes persons with disabilities, the elderly, pregnant women, and those with injuries who cannot use standard vehicles.

Public evacuation notices must include a specific hotline or method for people to request accessible transport. Inform the public that specialized assistance is available for those with mobility challenges.

Critical Protocol: A person must not be separated from their essential assistive devices, such as wheelchairs, walkers, or oxygen tanks. Ensure any transport vehicle used has adequate space for both the individual and their equipment.

Standard rescue boats or trucks may not be suitable for safe transport. Assess the individual's needs to determine if a vehicle with a ramp, lift, or space for a stretcher is required for a safe and dignified evacuation.

Individuals requiring accessible transport are to be considered a high-priority group during evacuations. Evacuation timelines and logistics must specifically account for the additional time and resources needed to assist them safely.

Response personnel should receive basic training on disability etiquette and safe handling techniques. This includes how to properly lift and transfer individuals and how to securely stow mobility devices during transport.

When arranging transport for a person with accessibility needs, ensure their primary caregiver or a family member can travel with them. Separating individuals from their support network should be avoided at all costs.

Maintain a central registry of available accessible vehicles (e.g., ambulances, modified vans) within the operational area. Dispatch these limited assets based on a priority system managed by the transport or medical unit.

Accessible transport planning must be end-to-end. It includes not just the initial rescue, but also transport from shelters to medical appointments, relief distribution points, and other essential services during the recovery phase.

Ensure that evacuation transport routes are planned to drop off individuals with mobility issues at pre-identified, fully accessible shelters. A shelter is not a viable destination if it has barriers like stairs or inaccessible bathrooms.

Extreme Danger: Treat all downed power lines as if they are live. Stay at least 10 meters (33 feet) away from them and anything they are touching. Report downed lines to emergency services immediately.

In areas with significant flooding, utility companies may perform a pre-emptive power shutdown. This is a necessary safety measure to prevent electrocution from submerged electrical equipment and to protect the grid from widespread damage.

Power restoration is prioritized for critical infrastructure. This includes hospitals and medical facilities, water treatment plants, communication hubs, and emergency shelters. Residential areas will be addressed once these are stable.

Households with members dependent on electricity-powered medical devices (e.g., ventilators, oxygen concentrators) should be registered as a priority. If extended outages are expected, plans must be made to relocate these individuals to a powered facility.

If using a portable generator for power, always operate it outdoors in a well-ventilated area, away from all windows and doors, to prevent lethal carbon monoxide poisoning. Never operate a generator inside a home or garage.

To report a power outage, please contact your utility provider directly through their designated channels. Do not use the national emergency hotline unless you are reporting a downed power line, fire, or other immediate life-threatening hazard.

Utility crews must conduct a full damage assessment of substations, transformers, and power lines in flooded areas before attempting to restore power. Re-energizing damaged equipment can cause fires and further damage to the grid.

If your home or business has been flooded, you must have a qualified electrician inspect your electrical system before turning the main breaker back on. Floodwater can severely damage wiring and outlets, creating a serious fire risk.

The Emergency Operations Center must maintain liaison with utility providers to receive regular updates. This includes outage maps, number of customers affected, crew deployment status, and estimated restoration times for different sectors.

We are working with the utility company to restore power as quickly as is safely possible. Due to extensive flood damage, some areas may experience prolonged outages. We will provide regular updates on the progress of restoration efforts.

CRITICAL DANGER: Never use a portable generator inside a home, garage, basement, or any enclosed area. Generators produce carbon monoxide (CO), a colorless, odorless gas that can cause sudden illness and death.

Place your generator outdoors on a stable, dry surface, at least 6 meters (20 feet) away from any doors, windows, and vents to prevent exhaust fumes from entering your home. Point the engine exhaust away from your house.
To prevent electrocution, keep the generator dry. Do not use it in rainy or wet conditions without protecting it with a canopy. Never touch a generator if you are wet or standing in water.

Always turn the generator off and let it cool down completely before refueling. Spilling fuel on a hot engine can ignite and cause a severe fire. Store fuel in an approved container away from the generator.

Never try to power your house by plugging the generator into a wall outlet, a practice known as 'backfeeding'. This is extremely dangerous and can cause fatal electrical shocks to utility workers and neighbors.

Use heavy-duty, outdoor-rated extension cords that are rated for the total wattage of the appliances you are connecting. Inspect cords for any cuts or damage before use. Ensure the cord has a grounding pin.

Install battery-operated carbon monoxide (CO) alarms inside your home, particularly near sleeping areas. These detectors are a critical life-saving tool that can alert you to the presence of CO gas from a generator.

Do not overload the generator. Add up the wattage of all lights and appliances you are connecting, and make sure it does not exceed the generator's power rating. This prevents overheating and damage to your equipment.

If a generator has been submerged in floodwater, do not use it. Water can damage the engine and electrical components, creating a risk of fire or electrical shock. It must be professionally inspected and serviced first.

If you rely on a generator to power life-support medical equipment, ensure you have enough fuel for several days and a backup plan in case of generator failure. Inform your local health services of your situation.

The highest priority for power restoration and backup fuel is for hospitals, especially those with Intensive Care Units (ICUs), operating theaters, and emergency trauma services. These facilities must remain operational for life-saving care.

Individuals at home who rely on powered life-support equipment, such as ventilators or dialysis machines, are a critical priority. They must be identified for urgent evacuation to a powered facility if their power cannot be restored immediately.

Power must be prioritized for all facilities maintaining the medical 'cold chain'. This includes refrigerators and freezers storing vaccines, blood products, and temperature-sensitive medications like insulin to prevent spoilage.

After major hospitals, the next priority for power are primary health clinics, field hospitals, and mobile medical units. These facilities are key to managing non-critical cases and preventing hospital overload.

Powering water pumps and sanitation systems at medical facilities is a critical priority. Without clean water, a hospital cannot function safely or maintain infection control, regardless of whether other equipment is powered.

Power should be allocated to support essential health communication networks. This includes systems used by ambulance dispatch, medical evacuation coordination, and inter-hospital communication to manage patient loads.

If you or a household member depends on powered medical equipment, you should pre-register with your local health authority and electricity provider. This helps emergency planners identify your needs during a power outage.

Medical facilities must have a power plan that prioritizes their own internal circuits. Life-support and critical diagnostic equipment should be connected to the backup power supply, while less critical functions like general lighting or administrative offices can wait.

Power for routine medical services, such as private specialist clinics (e.g., dental, optometry) and non-essential diagnostic labs, is a lower priority. Restoration will occur after critical health and public safety needs are met.
When assessing power needs, logistics teams must also plan for the fuel resupply chain for hospital generators. A generator without a reliable fuel source is not a viable long-term solution.

Establish community device charging hubs in safe, centrally located public buildings such as evacuation centers, schools, or community halls. The chosen site must be on high ground and confirmed to be structurally sound and free from water damage.

The power source for a charging hub, typically a generator, must be positioned safely outdoors on a dry surface, away from doors and windows. All electrical connections must be installed by a qualified technician to prevent fire and electrocution risks.

Electrical safety is paramount at charging hubs. All stations must use power strips with surge protectors and Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter (GFCI) protection. Keep all cables off the floor, and prohibit the charging of devices that are wet or visibly damaged.

Publicly announce the locations and operating hours of all official charging hubs. Information should be shared via radio and community leaders, specifying any rules, such as time limits, to ensure everyone is informed.

To ensure fair and equitable access, implement and clearly display rules, such as a time limit per person (e.g., 30-60 minutes), especially during peak demand. A simple ticketing system can help manage queues in an orderly fashion.

Charging hubs should be set up in well-lit, supervised areas to deter theft of devices. While users are primarily responsible for their belongings, the presence of staff or volunteers during operating hours is essential for security.

Give charging priority to essential communication devices, primarily mobile phones, which are vital for receiving emergency alerts and contacting family. Discourage the charging of non-essential entertainment devices if resources are limited.

To prevent the spread of illness, set up the charging station to allow for physical distancing. Provide hand sanitizer and regularly disinfect high-touch surfaces, such as charging cables and table edges.

Ensure the charging hub is inclusive. At least a portion of the charging outlets should be placed at a height accessible to a person in a wheelchair. Staff should be ready to assist persons with disabilities or the elderly.

Each charging hub requires management by at least one designated staff member or trained volunteer per shift. Their responsibilities include monitoring safety, managing queues, and providing assistance to users.

The medical cold chain is the system for storing and transporting vaccines and temperature-sensitive medicines within the safe range of +2°C to +8°C. Any deviation from this range can make them ineffective and unsafe.

During a power outage, keep the vaccine refrigerator door closed. A well-sealed unit can maintain its temperature for several hours. Prepare cold boxes and conditioned ice packs for emergency transfer if the outage is prolonged.

If a medical facility storing vaccines is at risk of flooding, the cold chain stock must be evacuated as a priority. Transfer all items to a pre-identified, secure alternate facility with a stable power source using validated cold boxes.

Crucial Step: Frozen ice packs must be 'conditioned' before use to prevent freezing the vaccines. Let them sit at ambient temperature until you can hear water sloshing inside. This ensures the temperature stays above 0°C.

The temperature of vaccine refrigerators must be monitored and recorded twice daily on a log chart. Any reading outside the +2°C to +8°C range constitutes a cold chain breach and must be reported immediately.

In case of a cold chain breach, immediately segregate the affected vaccines and label them 'DO NOT USE'. Quarantine the stock and report the incident to the national immunization program for a decision on whether the vaccines can still be used.

When transporting vaccines, use a validated cold box with a temperature monitoring device inside. Pack it correctly with conditioned ice packs and ensure it is not placed in direct sunlight during transit.

For individuals managing their own insulin supply during a flood-related power outage: do not let your insulin freeze. A current vial can be kept at room temperature (below 30°C) for up to 28 days. Protect your backup supply in a cooler with a cool pack, but not a frozen one.

Mobile health teams going into flood-affected areas should only carry enough vaccine for one day's work in a standard vaccine carrier. The remaining stock must be left in a stable, monitored refrigerator at the base.

Logistics teams must prioritize fuel for generators at facilities with cold chain equipment. A continuous power supply is the most effective way to protect these life-saving medical supplies during a disaster.

If mobile networks are congested after the flood, use SMS text messages for non-urgent communication instead of making voice calls. Text messages require less network bandwidth and are more likely to be delivered, keeping lines free for emergencies.

Telecommunication service providers must prioritize the restoration of network connectivity to critical facilities. This includes hospitals, Emergency Operations Centers (EOCs), police stations, and major evacuation shelters.

In areas where cell towers are damaged or destroyed by floods, mobile cell sites (e.g., Cell-on-Wheels or COWs) should be deployed to provide temporary communication coverage for responders and the affected community.

When conventional communication networks fail, all response teams must shift to designated backup systems. Command staff should use satellite phones, while field teams rely on VHF/UHF radios for operational coordination.

Public information regarding telecom outages will be broadcast over the radio. Stay tuned for updates on which service providers are affected, the geographic areas of the outage, and estimated timelines for restoration.

Conserve your mobile phone's battery. Switch to power-saving mode, reduce screen brightness, and turn off Wi-Fi and Bluetooth when not in use. A charged phone is a vital link to emergency information and help.

The Emergency Operations Center must maintain a direct liaison with all major telecom providers. This is essential for coordinating repair crew access to restricted areas and getting accurate updates on network status.

In a widespread outage, authorities may request mobile operators to enable national roaming. This would allow a user to connect to any available network, regardless of their own provider, increasing the chances of making a call.

Consider setting up temporary public Wi-Fi hotspots at evacuation centers and relief distribution points. This allows affected people to use data services for communication and information, reducing congestion on the voice network.
In areas with no connectivity, send runners or messengers to relay critical information between field teams and the command post. Do not let a communication failure halt life-saving operations.

The activation of satellite communication systems is authorized when terrestrial networks (cellular, landline) are confirmed to be down in the disaster area. This action establishes a resilient backup link for critical command and control functions.

Satellite phones must be distributed according to operational priority. The first recipients include the Incident Commander, leaders of forward search and rescue teams, and key coordinators at the Emergency Operations Center.

To get a signal on a satellite phone, you must have a clear, unobstructed line of sight to the sky. Move away from buildings, dense tree cover, or deep valleys. Extend the antenna fully and point it towards the sky.

All satellite communications must be for essential operational traffic only. Keep calls brief and concise to conserve airtime, which is a limited and costly resource. State your name, location, and message clearly.

Deploy Broadband Global Area Network (BGAN) terminals at command posts and field coordination hubs to establish internet connectivity. This is vital for sending emails, downloading maps, and transmitting situation reports.

Power management for satellite devices is critical. Each deployed kit must include fully charged batteries and a method for recharging, such as a solar panel or a small generator, to ensure continuous operation.

Each satellite phone should be issued with a laminated card listing the pre-approved contact numbers for key operational personnel and command centers. This ensures teams can communicate with the right people quickly.

Field teams equipped with satellite phones must follow a communications plan that includes scheduled check-in times with the command post. This protocol ensures team safety and a regular flow of information.

Please be aware that satellite phones are specialized devices for emergency responders and are not part of the public network. To report an emergency, continue to use standard numbers like 119; your call will be routed if any network is available.

In exceptional, life-or-death circumstances, a response team may assist a member of the public in making a brief, critical call using a satellite phone. This is solely at the discretion of the team leader and is not a public service.

Integrate real-time data feeds from automated river level gauges into the central monitoring system. The system must be configured to trigger automatic alerts to operators when water levels cross pre-defined warning, alert, and danger thresholds.

Establish a social media monitoring feed using specific keywords and geographic filters to capture public posts requesting help or reporting flood conditions. This provides valuable, real-time ground truth but requires verification.

Verification Protocol: Any actionable intelligence from an unverified feed, such as a social media report of a building collapse, must be corroborated by at least one other source (e.g., a call from an official, drone imagery) before committing major resources.

Live video feeds from aerial drones and satellite imagery must be integrated directly into the GIS platform. This allows for rapid damage assessment and real-time mapping of flood extent to guide search and rescue teams to isolated areas.

Integrate real-time traffic data from police departments and public navigation apps. This feed is used to maintain a live map of road closures and traffic bottlenecks, which is critical for planning safe evacuation and emergency vehicle routes.

Establish an API connection to the national electricity provider to feed real-time power outage maps into the common operational picture. This helps prioritize fuel allocation and identify critical facilities running on backup power.

Anonymized location data from emergency hotlines (like 119) should be visualized as a real-time heat map. This helps the Emergency Operations Center identify clusters of distress calls and dynamically allocate rescue assets to the areas of greatest need.

All incoming real-time data feeds must be aggregated and displayed on a unified Common Operational Picture (COP). This layered map view provides a single source of truth for all decision-makers during the response.

Every data point from a live feed must have a clear timestamp. Operators must understand the latency of each data source (e.g., weather radar is near-instant, some satellite images may be hours old) to make timely and informed decisions.

Integrate data from GPS trackers on emergency vehicles and response teams. This allows dispatchers to monitor asset locations in real-time, assign the closest team to a new incident, and ensure personnel accountability.

Social Media Template (Donations): 'Many people want to help. The most effective way is through a financial donation to organizations like the Sri Lanka Red Cross at [link]. This allows us to buy exactly what is needed. Please avoid donating physical items for now.'
