Joint Press Conference Opening Statement Template: 'Good morning. This is a joint operational briefing on the flood response. We will provide updates on search and rescue, relief distribution, and public health measures. We are committed to a coordinated and transparent response.'

Public Contact: For all life-threatening flood emergencies, including requests for immediate rescue, the public should call the national emergency hotline at 119. This is the primary and most direct line for assistance.

Responder Contact (Operations): Field teams requiring tactical assignments, reporting completion of tasks, or requesting operational support (e.g., more boats) must contact the Operations Section Chief at the Command Post.

Responder Contact (Logistics): For all supply and support needs, including fuel, food, water, and equipment repair, the point of contact is the Logistics Section Chief. Submit all resource requests through this channel.

Media Contact: All inquiries from the media must be directed to the Public Information Officer (PIO). The PIO is the sole official source of information for the incident. Responders in the field should not speak to the press.

Responder Contact (Safety): Immediately report any accident, injury, or unsafe condition to the designated Safety Officer. The Safety Officer has the authority to stop or modify any operation that poses an imminent threat to personnel.

Inter-Agency Contact: Representatives from partner agencies (e.g., UN, NGOs) arriving to assist must first report to the Liaison Officer at the Incident Command Post to ensure their activities are coordinated with the overall response.

Responder Contact (Planning): Submit all field observations, damage assessments, and situational updates to the Planning Section Chief. This information is vital for developing the Incident Action Plan for the next operational period.

Responder Contact (Medical): To request medical support for a responder or to coordinate emergency medical services in the field, contact the Medical Unit Leader. For civilian medical emergencies, use the main dispatch channel.

Volunteer Contact: Individuals who wish to volunteer should not go directly to the disaster site. Please register through the official Sri Lanka Red Cross website or other designated volunteer reception centers.

Responder Contact (Air Ops): All requests for aviation resources, such as helicopters for rescue or drones for reconnaissance, must be routed through the Operations Section Chief to the Air Operations Branch Director.

Overall Coordination Lead: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN OCHA) facilitates inter-cluster coordination. Contact the OCHA representative for high-level strategic issues, consolidated situation reports, and information on humanitarian financing.

Health Cluster Lead: The World Health Organization (WHO) leads the Health Cluster. All organizations involved in medical response, disease surveillance, or health promotion should coordinate their activities through the Health Cluster Lead.

WASH Cluster Lead: UNICEF leads the Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) Cluster. Contact the WASH Cluster Lead to coordinate all activities related to providing safe drinking water, building latrines, and promoting hygiene in flood-affected areas.

Shelter Cluster Lead: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) is the lead for the Shelter Cluster. Contact this lead to coordinate the distribution of emergency shelter supplies (tarps, tents) and essential non-food items.

Food Security Cluster Lead: This cluster, led globally by WFP and FAO, is the primary contact for coordinating food aid. All partners involved in general food distribution or nutritional programs must coordinate with this cluster's lead.

Nutrition Cluster Lead: UNICEF leads the Nutrition Cluster. This is the primary contact for all partners working on preventing and treating malnutrition, with a focus on young children and pregnant or lactating women.

Protection Cluster Lead: This cluster, led globally by UNHCR, focuses on the safety and rights of affected people. Contact this lead for issues related to child protection, gender-based violence (GBV), and assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs).

National Government Lead: The National Disaster Management Centre (NDMC) is the primary government authority. All cluster activities must be conducted in close coordination with and in support of the NDMC's overall response plan.

Logistics Cluster Lead: This cluster, led globally by WFP, provides coordination for the entire humanitarian supply chain. Contact the Logistics Cluster Lead for support with common warehousing, transportation, and customs clearance for relief items.

Camp Management (CCCM) Cluster Lead: This cluster, led globally by IOM and UNHCR, is the main point of contact for managing and coordinating services within official evacuation centers and displacement sites.

Data Privacy Principle: Before collecting personal data from a flood-affected person, you must obtain their informed consent. Clearly explain why their information is needed, how it will be used for assistance, and how it will be protected.

Data Privacy Principle: Only collect the minimum personal data necessary to provide aid. Do not ask for sensitive information that is not directly required for the specific humanitarian service you are delivering.

Record Backup Protocol: All critical digital records, such as beneficiary registration lists and damage assessments, must be backed up from field devices to a secure, remote or cloud-based server at least once per day.

Digital Security: Any device (laptop, tablet, phone) used to collect or store personally identifiable information must be password-protected and have its storage encrypted. This prevents unauthorized data access if a device is lost or stolen.

Physical Security: Paper-based forms containing private information must be stored securely in a locked box or cabinet when not in active use. Never leave sensitive records unattended in a public area like a shelter.

Data Sharing Protocol: When sharing information for general reporting, all personal data must be anonymized. Report aggregated data (e.g., '200 families assisted in this district') rather than individual case files.

Access Control: Access to beneficiary data is restricted on a strict 'need-to-know' basis. Response personnel should only be granted access to the specific information required for their assigned tasks.

Record Backup Protocol: For the main command center, a complete backup of all operational data must be performed daily, with the physical backup media stored at a secure, off-site location outside the immediate flood risk zone.

Data Destruction Policy: At the conclusion of the response and recovery operation, all personally identifiable information must be securely destroyed in accordance with the organization's data retention policy to protect the long-term privacy of beneficiaries.

Public Information on Privacy: 'To receive assistance, we may need to ask for personal information. This is to ensure aid is distributed fairly. Your data will be kept secure and confidential and will only be used for humanitarian purposes.'

GBV Core Principle: The survivor-centered approach is mandatory. All actions must prioritize the survivor's safety, confidentiality, and their right to make their own decisions. Respect their wishes at all times.

GBV Protocol: Strict confidentiality is non-negotiable. Do not share any information about a survivor or a reported incident with anyone—including other staff or family members—without the survivor's explicit informed consent.

GBV Referral Step 1 (Medical): For sexual assault survivors, the immediate priority is confidential access to clinical care within 72 hours for Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) against HIV and other health services. This is a time-critical referral.

GBV Referral Step 2 (Psychosocial): Refer the survivor to a designated Women and Girls Safe Space or a trained psychosocial support (PSS) provider. These services offer a safe environment, emotional support, and further confidential guidance.

GBV Protocol (Informed Consent): Before making a referral, you must explain what services are available (medical, safety, psychological) and get the survivor's informed consent to proceed. A survivor always has the right to refuse any or all services.

Warning for All Responders: Your role is to support and refer, NOT to investigate. Do not ask for details about the incident unless necessary for immediate safety, and never confront the alleged perpetrator. Investigation is for specialized personnel only.

GBV Referral Step 3 (Safety/Shelter): Assess the survivor's immediate safety. If they are at risk of further harm, coordinate with protection officers to facilitate their move to a secure location or a safe shelter that can accommodate GBV survivors.

Public Information Template: 'Confidential support for women and girls is available at all Red Cross health posts and designated safe spaces in the camps. Please speak to our female staff. Your safety and privacy are our priority.'

GBV Coordination: The Protection Cluster is responsible for developing, updating, and sharing the official GBV referral pathway map. This document lists all available medical, psychosocial, safety, and legal services with contact details for responders.

GBV Referral Step 4 (Legal): Inform the survivor of their right to seek legal justice, but do not pressure them. If they consent, provide contact information for free legal aid services or guide them to the appropriate police contact who is trained in handling GBV cases.

Child Protection Priority: The primary goal during evacuation and response is to keep children with their families. Actively work to prevent family separation. A child separated from their caregiver is at a significantly higher risk of harm.

UASC Protocol: If you find an Unaccompanied or Separated Child (UASC), bring them to a designated safe area immediately. Do not question them extensively. Report their presence to a registered child protection agency like the Red Cross or UNICEF for formal registration and family tracing.

Establish Child-Friendly Spaces in all large evacuation centers. These are monitored, safe environments where children can play, receive psychosocial support, and regain a sense of normalcy away from the stresses of the main shelter.

Media Protocol: Do not photograph, film, or interview children in a way that reveals their identity or location, especially if they are unaccompanied. This is to protect their privacy and shield them from potential exploitation or trafficking.

Shelter Safety Protocol: Ensure evacuation centers have well-lit areas, especially near toilets and washing facilities, to reduce risks. Families should be allocated space together, and separate from single adults where possible.

Code of Conduct: All personnel and volunteers interacting with children must be briefed on and sign a strict Code of Conduct. This code must explicitly forbid any form of abuse, exploitation, or inappropriate relationship with a child.

Adoption Warning: Informal or 'on the spot' adoption of children who appear to be alone is strictly prohibited. A child's parents may be alive but separated by the flood. All such cases must be referred to national child welfare authorities.

Infant Feeding Protocol: Inappropriate donations of infant formula and bottles can be dangerous. Promote and support breastfeeding for infants. If formula is medically required, it must be prepared with safe, boiled water by trained staff.

Public Information Template: 'If you have found a child who is alone, please bring them to the nearest Red Cross point or police station. If you have lost your child, report it there. We have a system to help reunite families safely.'

Referral Protocol: Any child who discloses abuse or shows signs of severe psychological distress or injury must be confidentially and immediately referred to a specialized case worker from a child protection agency for professional support.

Communication Accommodation: All emergency alerts, safety messages, and information on services must be delivered in multiple formats. This includes using simple language, large text, audio broadcasts, and sign language interpretation to reach people with different disabilities.

Shelter Accommodation: Official evacuation centers must be physically accessible. This means having step-free access (ramps), ground-floor sleeping areas, and at least one accessible toilet and washing facility. Conduct an accessibility audit before opening a shelter.

Assistive Device Protocol: It is critical that persons are not separated from their assistive devices (e.g., wheelchairs, prosthetics, hearing aids, white canes). Ensure there is space in evacuation vehicles and secure, dry storage at shelters for these essential items.

Registration Protocol: When registering people for aid, respectfully ask if they or a family member require any specific accommodation due to a disability or chronic health condition. This allows for targeted support and appropriate referrals.

Distribution Accommodation: At food and non-food item distribution points, establish a clearly marked, prioritized lane for persons with disabilities, the elderly, and pregnant women to ensure they can receive aid safely and without long waits.

Evacuation Accommodation: When a rescue request is received from a person with a disability, the dispatch team must be notified of their specific needs (e.g., wheelchair user, deaf) so the correct personnel and equipment can be sent.

WASH Accommodation: All water points and latrines in shelters must be accessible. This includes having a clear, flat path, adequate lighting, non-slip surfaces, and enough space for a wheelchair user and a caregiver if needed.

Public Information Template: 'Support is available for persons with disabilities. If you require accessible transport or have specific needs at a shelter, please call our special assistance hotline at [Hotline Number].'

Participation Principle: Ensure that persons with disabilities and their representative organizations are actively involved in the planning, implementation, and monitoring of all flood response and recovery programs.

Medical Accommodation: Ensure that people with chronic health conditions have continuous access to their medications and necessary medical care. This may require arranging transport to clinics or ensuring cold-chain for medicines like insulin.

Checklist Item: Ask if they take regular medication for chronic illnesses (e.g., diabetes, high blood pressure). Confirm they have at least a one-week supply and that it is stored in a waterproof bag. If not, this is a priority medical need.

Checklist Item: Assess their mobility. Can they walk without help, or do they use a cane, walker, or wheelchair? This information is vital for arranging the correct type of transport for a safe evacuation.
Checklist Item: Check for vision or hearing impairments. Ensure they have their glasses and hearing aids. When communicating, face them directly, speak clearly, and use simple, short sentences.
Checklist Item (Shelter): Assign elderly individuals to ground-floor sleeping areas in evacuation centers, close to accessible and well-lit toilet facilities to minimize movement and risk of falls.
Checklist Item: Monitor for dehydration and nutritional needs. Ensure they are drinking enough water and can eat the food provided. If they have trouble chewing, arrange for softer food options.

Checklist Item: Look for signs of distress, confusion, or social isolation. Encourage them to talk with family or staff. Connect them with psychosocial support volunteers for a friendly chat and emotional support.

Checklist Item (Safety): Keep walking paths in shelters and aid points clear of obstacles, cords, and water spills to prevent falls, which are a major risk for older adults in unfamiliar environments.

Public Information Template: 'Check on your elderly neighbors and relatives. Help them prepare a go-bag with their medicines and important documents. In a disaster, a caring community is the best defense.'

Checklist Item: Ensure elderly individuals are receiving and understanding key public announcements. If necessary, assign a volunteer or staff member to communicate important updates to them directly.

Checklist Item (Recovery): Plan for continuity of care. After the immediate crisis, ensure elderly persons can access prescription refills, follow-up medical appointments, and any specialized care they require for chronic conditions.

Public Information: To help safely, please do NOT self-deploy to the flood zone. Unsolicited volunteers can disrupt professional rescue operations. Instead, register through official channels like the Sri Lanka Red Cross website.

Volunteer Registration Protocol: All prospective volunteers must be directed to a designated Volunteer Reception Center (VRC) away from the immediate impact zone. No on-site registration of unaffiliated individuals will occur in operational areas.

Verification Step 1 (ID Check): All volunteers must present a valid government-issued photo identification (e.g., National Identity Card) at the VRC. No individual will be registered without positive identification.

Verification Step (Medical Professionals): Any volunteer presenting as a doctor, nurse, or paramedic must have their professional license and registration verified with the Sri Lanka Medical Council or other relevant authority before they are assigned to any clinical role.

Safeguarding Protocol: Any volunteer being assigned to a role with direct, unsupervised contact with children MUST undergo a background check. This is a non-negotiable step to protect vulnerable populations.

Deployment Protocol: After verification, every volunteer must be issued an official ID card and/or vest identifying their name, organization, and role. This identification must be worn and visible at all times while on duty.

Deployment Protocol: Before starting any task, all verified volunteers must attend a mandatory Just-In-Time Training. This briefing covers safety protocols, their specific duties, the Code of Conduct, and who to report to.

Verification Step 2 (Skills Matching): During intake, briefly interview volunteers to determine their skills, experience, and physical capabilities. Match volunteers to appropriate tasks to ensure both safety and operational effectiveness.

Public Warning: Be aware that not everyone offering help is official. All verified aid workers and volunteers will carry proper identification. Do not give cash to individuals. Donate to registered, well-known organizations.

Volunteer Demobilization: At the end of their service, all volunteers must be formally checked out. This process includes returning ID cards and equipment, conducting an exit briefing, and offering psychosocial support if needed.

Decision Rule (Default Choice): Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA) should be the preferred and default method of providing aid. In-kind assistance should only be chosen when there is a specific, evidence-based reason why cash is not appropriate.

Decision Rule (Market Functionality): Provide cash only if local markets are physically accessible, safe, and have a sufficient supply of essential goods. If markets are destroyed or goods are unavailable, in-kind aid is necessary.

Decision Rule (Beneficiary Preference): The choice between cash and in-kind aid must be informed by the expressed preferences of the affected population. Conduct rapid assessments to ask people what form of assistance they need and prefer.

Decision Rule (Security): If there are significant safety risks associated with carrying cash, such as theft or extortion, in-kind aid or vouchers delivered to a secure distribution point may be the safer option for beneficiaries.

Decision Rule (Financial Infrastructure): Cash assistance is only viable if there are accessible and functioning financial service providers (e.g., banks, mobile money agents) that can handle the volume of transfers. Otherwise, in-kind is required.

Decision Rule (Specific Needs): In-kind distribution is often more appropriate for meeting highly specific technical needs, such as specialized nutritional supplements for malnourished children or cholera treatment kits, to ensure correct usage.

Decision Rule (Inflation Risk): Before launching a large-scale cash program, analyze the risk of causing harmful price inflation in local markets. If the risk is high, consider vouchers or a combination of cash and in-kind aid.

Decision Rule (Speed): In the first 72 hours of a rapid-onset flood, distributing pre-positioned in-kind goods may be faster than setting up a cash transfer system. The priority is to deliver life-saving aid as quickly as possible.

Decision Rule (Vouchers): Use vouchers as a middle ground when markets are working but you need to encourage the purchase of specific items, such as shelter repair kits or agricultural tools, to support early recovery.

Public Information Template: 'To support your recovery, we will be providing assistance through [cash transfers/vouchers/food parcels]. This decision was made based on market conditions and community feedback to ensure you can access the help you need most.'

Verification Principle: Effective verification is based on a robust initial registration. A master beneficiary list created during registration is the primary tool against which individuals are verified at the time of aid distribution.

Verification Method 1 (Official ID): The primary verification method is a government-issued photo ID, like a National Identity Card (NIC). The name and ID number must match the details on the master distribution list.

Verification Method 2 (Aid Token): If official documents were lost in the flood, use an agency-issued ration card or token given during registration. This token should have a unique household number or QR code that can be checked.

Verification Method 3 (Community Confirmation): In communities where many have lost documents, a designated and trusted community leader or committee can verbally verify a beneficiary's identity. This must be formally documented on the distribution sheet.

Duplication Check Protocol: Before distribution, beneficiary lists must be cross-checked with those of other organizations working in the same area. This de-duplication process is essential to ensure fair distribution and prevent fraud.

Public Information Template: 'To collect your relief package, please bring your National ID card or the distribution card you received from the Red Cross. This helps us ensure that aid reaches the correct registered families.'

Exception Handling Protocol: Every distribution point must have a designated desk for handling complaints and exceptions. A senior staff member must be available to assist people who are not on the list but believe they should be.

Post-Verification Protocol: After receiving aid, the beneficiary's ration card should be marked or stamped. Using indelible ink on a finger (with consent) is another effective method to prevent individuals from receiving aid multiple times in one distribution cycle.

Proxy Collection Protocol: For registered beneficiaries who are unable to come to the distribution point (e.g., elderly, sick, persons with severe disabilities), a pre-designated alternate family member may collect on their behalf. This must be noted during registration.

Verification Method 4 (Biometric): In programs with biometric registration, use fingerprint or iris scanners for verification. This provides the highest level of assurance but requires that data was collected with informed consent and is managed securely.

Receiving Protocol: All incoming relief supplies must be recorded on a Goods Received Note (GRN). This note must detail the donor/supplier, item description, quantity, and condition upon arrival. This is the first and most critical step in the tracking process.

Inventory System: A stock card (physical or digital) must be maintained for every single line item in the warehouse. Every movement of that item, in or out, must be recorded on the card immediately to maintain a real-time balance.

Storage Principle (FEFO): For items with an expiry date, such as food and medicines, the 'First-Expiry, First-Out' principle is mandatory. Stock with the soonest expiry date must always be dispatched first to prevent wastage.

Flood Mitigation in Warehouse: All relief items must be stored on pallets or shelving at least 15 cm (6 inches) off the ground. This protects critical supplies from damage caused by ground-level flooding or water seepage.

Dispatch Protocol: No goods may leave the warehouse without an authorized Waybill or Stock Release Form. This document serves as a receipt and tracking mechanism, detailing what was sent, to whom, and for what purpose.

Reporting Protocol: The warehouse manager must provide a daily inventory report to the Logistics Section of the EOC. This report should summarize stock levels of critical items, expected arrivals, and total dispatches for the day.

Verification Protocol: Conduct weekly physical inventory counts ('spot checks') on a random selection of high-value items. This helps ensure that the recorded stock levels are accurate and identifies any discrepancies early.

Storage Protocol (Segregation): Store food items separately from non-food items like soap, fuel, or chemicals to prevent cross-contamination. Medical supplies should be kept in a secure, climate-controlled area.

Damaged Stock Protocol: Any supplies damaged by floodwater or other means must be immediately removed from general stock, recorded on a loss report, and disposed of according to safety guidelines. Never distribute compromised goods.

System Protocol: Ideally, a centralized digital inventory management system should be used to link all warehouses. This provides a single, real-time view of the entire supply chain, allowing for better planning and allocation of relief items.

Distribution Site Selection: The chosen site must be safe, easily accessible for beneficiaries, and reachable by supply trucks. It should have ample space for queuing, clear entry/exit points, and be on ground that is not at risk of flooding.

Pre-Distribution Communication: Inform the community at least 24 hours in advance of any planned distribution. The message must clearly state the date, time, location, items available, and what identification (e.g., ration card) is required.

Crowd Control SOP: Use ropes, signs, and volunteers to establish a clear and orderly queue. Ensure separate entry and exit points to maintain a smooth flow of people and prevent overcrowding. Communicate instructions calmly using a megaphone.

Distribution Process Step 1 (Verification): The first station in the distribution line must be the verification desk. Staff will check the beneficiary's ID or ration card against the official, pre-approved list before they can proceed.

Equity Protocol: A separate, clearly marked, and prioritized 'fast-track' lane must be established for persons with disabilities, the elderly, pregnant women, and households with young children to ensure their safe and dignified access to aid.

Accountability Protocol: Each distribution site must have a complaints and feedback desk located in a visible but discreet area. This allows beneficiaries to report issues, such as being excluded from lists or staff misconduct, in a safe manner.

Post-Distribution Monitoring (PDM): Within 1-2 weeks after a distribution, conduct random household surveys to confirm aid was received, assess its appropriateness and quality, and gather feedback to improve future distributions.

Site Security SOP: Coordinate with local authorities to ensure a security presence at the distribution site. All relief supplies must be kept in a secure, guarded area. Staff must have a clear evacuation plan in case of a security threat.

End-of-Day Reconciliation: At the close of distribution, the team leader must reconcile records. The number of beneficiaries served (from signed lists) must match the number of aid packages dispatched from the stock. All remaining items must be counted and secured.

Standard Relief Package: A standard family relief package should be pre-defined and consistent. For a flood, this typically includes rice, lentils, sugar, oil, soap, water purification tablets, and a tarpaulin, designed to last a family for one week.

Procurement Protocol: All procurement requests must be channeled through the designated Logistics/Procurement Officer at the Emergency Operations Center (EOC). Field teams are not authorized to make independent purchases of goods or services.

Medical Procurement Contact: For all pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and clinical supplies, the procurement request must be technically approved by the Health Cluster Lead (WHO) before being processed by the logistics team to ensure quality standards.

Shelter & NFI Contact: To purchase bulk non-food items (NFIs) such as tarpaulins, blankets, and kitchen sets, contact the IFRC logistics delegate. They manage pre-existing agreements with regional suppliers for these items.

Transport Procurement Contact: For contracting local transport, including boats, trucks, or buses, all requests must be submitted to the Logistics Section. They are responsible for vetting providers and managing rental agreements.

Government Procurement Contact: For large-scale procurement utilizing state funds, the request must be formally submitted to the head of procurement at the National Disaster Management Centre (NDMC) for processing according to government tender procedures.

WASH Procurement Contact: For all Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) supplies, such as water purification tablets, pumps, and latrine slabs, the point of contact for procurement is the UNICEF Supply & Logistics section.

Vendor Contact Point: Local businesses that wish to be considered as suppliers for the flood response should register on the official vendor database. The link can be found on the NDMC website. Please do not contact the EOC directly.

Emergency Authorization Contact: For urgent, life-saving procurement that must bypass standard channels, direct authorization from the Incident Commander or the Director of Disaster Operations is required. A justification must be documented.

Fraud Reporting Contact: To report suspected corruption, collusion, or fraud in any procurement process, contact the confidential reporting channel provided by the lead humanitarian agency. This ensures accountability in the response.

Food Procurement Contact: For purchasing bulk food items like rice and lentils, the primary contact is the procurement officer of the lead food security agency (e.g., Red Cross, WFP). They will engage with pre-qualified vendors to ensure quality.

Last-Mile Strategy: Use a 'hub-and-spoke' model. Move bulk supplies from the main warehouse to smaller, forward distribution hubs located closer to affected areas. This shortens the final, most challenging delivery leg to the community.

Transport Selection: Standard trucks are often unusable. Last-mile logistics in flooded areas require alternative transport such as boats, tractors, high-clearance military vehicles, or, as a last resort, helicopters for airdrops.

Local Partner Engagement: Coordinate all last-mile deliveries with local government officials (e.g., Grama Niladhari) and community leaders. Their knowledge of safe routes, local conditions, and population needs is essential for effective delivery.

Repackaging Protocol: At forward hubs, break down bulk supplies from pallets and repackage them into standardized family kits. These kits should be a manageable weight and size for transport by small boats or for people to carry by hand.

Proof of Delivery: The team leader of every last-mile delivery must obtain a signed and dated receipt from the community representative at the destination. This document, confirming the items and quantities delivered, is crucial for accountability.

Safety Protocol: All personnel involved in last-mile deliveries via boat MUST wear a personal flotation device (life jacket). Missions must be cancelled or postponed if weather conditions or water currents are deemed unsafe.

Community Communication: Before dispatching a delivery, the logistics team should, if possible, communicate the estimated time of arrival and the contents of the shipment to the community leader to ensure they are prepared to receive and distribute the aid.

Airdrop Protocol: Airdrops are a high-cost, last-resort option for completely cut-off communities. They require a designated and safe drop zone, specialized packaging, and a pre-positioned ground team to secure and manage the distribution immediately.

Information Feedback Loop: Last-mile delivery teams must be debriefed upon their return. They are a critical source of on-the-ground intelligence regarding access routes, security conditions, and newly identified needs within the community.

Utilizing Local Transport: For terrain inaccessible by standard vehicles or boats, consider contracting local transport methods, such as porters, pack animals, or small carts. All such arrangements must be formally managed by the logistics unit.

Logistics Protocol: A dedicated cold-chain manager within the Health Cluster must be the central point of contact for coordinating the movement of all temperature-sensitive medical supplies. This ensures a synchronized and efficient response.

Preparedness SOP: Maintain pre-positioned stockpiles of essential cold-chain equipment, such as passive cold boxes, ice packs, and temperature loggers, in strategic district warehouses located outside of known flood zones for rapid deployment.

Asset Mapping: A real-time inventory of all functional cold-chain assets must be maintained. This includes locations of vaccine refrigerators with backup power, availability of refrigerated vehicles, and stocks of cold boxes across all partner agencies.

Transport Contingency Plan: When roads are impassable due to flooding, a contingency plan for cold-chain transport must be activated. This may involve using boats, helicopters, or other non-standard vehicles coordinated through the Logistics Cluster.

Last-Mile Delivery: For the final delivery to remote or isolated health posts, use validated vaccine carriers packed by trained staff. Only carry enough supplies for the immediate need to minimize the risk of temperature excursion.

Power Supply Priority: Health facilities with vaccine refrigerators are a top priority for fuel allocation to power their backup generators. The EOC logistics section must ensure these facilities have an uninterrupted fuel supply.

Transit Monitoring Protocol: Every shipment of vaccines must be accompanied by a temperature monitoring device. The data from this device must be checked upon arrival to verify that the cold chain was maintained throughout the journey.

Inter-Agency Coordination: All available cold-chain assets, such as refrigerated trucks, should be registered with the Logistics Cluster to be used as a common service for all humanitarian partners, maximizing efficiency and preventing duplication.

Reverse Logistics SOP: Implement a system for the recovery and return of reusable cold-chain equipment like high-quality cold boxes and electronic temperature loggers. This ensures valuable assets are not lost and can be redeployed.

Public Information: 'If you need to evacuate and take refrigerated medicine like insulin, place it in a cooler with a cool pack, not a frozen one. Immediately inform staff at the evacuation shelter that you have medicine requiring cold storage.'

Map Layer (Base Map): The foundation of any operational map is a high-resolution base layer. Use recent satellite imagery or a detailed road map (like OpenStreetMap) to provide essential geographic context for all other data.

Map Layer (Flood Inundation): The most critical layer, showing the current extent of floodwaters. This is typically derived from satellite (SAR) data or aerial reconnaissance and must be updated daily to guide rescue and relief operations.

Map Layer (Critical Infrastructure): A layer plotting the locations of essential facilities such as hospitals, police stations, water treatment plants, electrical substations, and schools designated as potential shelters.

Map Layer (Live Incidents): A real-time layer that plots incoming emergency calls and verified social media reports as points on the map. Each point should be categorized (e.g., rescue needed, medical, infrastructure damage) to guide immediate response.

Map Layer (Road Status): The road network should be displayed as a dynamic layer with segments color-coded based on their condition: Green (Passable), Amber (Caution/4x4 Only), and Red (Impassable/Flooded). This is vital for logistics.

Map Layer (Shelter Status): A layer showing the locations of all official evacuation centers. Each shelter's icon should indicate its operational status (e.g., open, full, closed) and its current occupancy level.

Map Layer (Population Density): Overlay a population density heat map. When combined with the flood inundation layer, this provides a rapid, initial estimate of the number of people affected and helps prioritize areas for assessment.

Map Layer (Health Facilities): A dedicated layer that maps all hospitals, clinics, and rural health centers. The layer must be updated with the operational status of each facility (e.g., functional, damaged, inaccessible) during the flood.

Map Layer (Response Assets): A real-time layer showing the locations of key response assets. This includes the command post, logistics hubs, ambulance staging areas, and the GPS tracks of mobile rescue teams.

Map Layer (Vulnerable Zones): A layer that identifies areas known to have high concentrations of vulnerable populations, such as informal settlements in low-lying areas, nursing homes, or orphanages, to prioritize welfare checks and assistance.

Landslide Warning Trigger: Landslide warnings are issued based on accumulated rainfall. A 'Watch' (Level 1) is typically issued for 75mm of rain, and a mandatory 'Evacuation' (Level 3 - Red Alert) for 150mm of rain within 24 hours in high-risk zones.

Public Alert Template: 'LANDSLIDE WARNING for [Village/Grama Niladhari Division]. Due to heavy rain, your area is at extreme risk. Evacuate immediately to the designated safe location at [Shelter Name]. Do not wait for further signs. - NDMC'

Warning Sign 1 (Ground Changes): Be alert for new cracks appearing on slopes, ground, floors, or roads. If existing cracks start to widen, this is a sign of ground movement and you should evacuate immediately.
Warning Sign 2 (Tilted Objects): Look for trees, fences, or utility poles that are tilting or moving. This indicates that the ground beneath them is unstable and could give way.

Warning Sign 3 (Unusual Sounds): If you hear a faint rumbling sound that slowly gets louder, a landslide may be approaching. Evacuate to the nearest high, stable ground immediately. Do not stay to investigate the sound.

Warning Sign 4 (Water Changes): Be aware of sudden changes in water flow. If a clear stream suddenly turns muddy, or if new springs or wet spots appear on a hillside, the ground is overly saturated and at risk of failure.

Evacuation Protocol: When evacuating from a landslide risk area, move across the slope (laterally) to the nearest stable ground. Avoid moving downhill into valleys or towards rivers, as these could be in the path of a debris flow.

Risk Mapping Protocol: All operational maps for flood response must include the official Landslide Hazard Zonation Map as a key layer. This allows for targeted warnings and proactive evacuation of pre-identified high-risk communities.

Re-entry Warning: Landslide risk can remain very high even after heavy rain has stopped. Do not return to evacuated areas until they have been assessed by geotechnical experts and declared safe by the authorities.

Responder Safety Protocol: Access to roads within Level 3 (Red Alert) landslide warning zones is strictly forbidden for all personnel until the alert level is lowered. This includes both response and civilian vehicles.

Public Warning: Assume all floodwater is contaminated. It can contain hazardous chemicals from industrial sites, pesticides from farms, and fuel from vehicles. Avoid all direct contact with floodwater whenever possible.

Hazard Identification: Be alert for signs of chemical contamination in water, such as a multi-colored oily sheen, unusual colors, a strong chemical odor, or large numbers of dead fish or animals. Report these signs immediately.

Responder Safety (PPE): All responders working in or near floodwater must wear appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), including waterproof boots, gloves, and eye protection. If a chemical hazard is suspected, a higher level of chemical-resistant gear is required.

Containment Protocol: Upon identifying a significant chemical spill, the first action is to establish a secure perimeter and deny entry to everyone, including standard responders. Only a trained HAZMAT team should enter the hot zone.

Specific Hazard (Agrochemicals): In rural areas, be aware that floodwater may be contaminated with pesticides and fertilizers from agricultural storage facilities. These chemicals can cause skin irritation and are toxic if swallowed.

Decontamination Protocol: If you make contact with floodwater, especially if you suspect chemical contamination, wash the affected area with soap and clean water as soon as possible. If you feel unwell after exposure, seek immediate medical attention.

Water Safety Warning: Water that is chemically contaminated cannot be made safe by boiling or standard disinfection tablets. Do not attempt to treat or use this water for any purpose. Depend only on officially approved safe water sources.

Household Cleanup Hazard: When cleaning your home after a flood, be careful with containers of household chemicals, paint, or fuel. They may have been damaged and leaked. Wear gloves and masks and ensure the area is well-ventilated.

Risk Mapping Protocol: All operational flood maps must include a layer showing the locations of high-risk industrial sites, fuel storage depots, and major agricultural chemical warehouses to anticipate potential Natech (Natural-hazard triggered technological) events.

Public Reporting Protocol: If you witness a major chemical spill, move to a safe distance upwind, and report it to the 119 emergency hotline immediately. Provide the exact location and describe any visible plumes or odors.

Alert Protocol: Official meteorological alerts are issued by the Department of Meteorology. The National Disaster Management Centre (NDMC) is responsible for disseminating these warnings to the public and all response agencies through official channels.

Alert Level 1 (Yellow - Be Aware): A Yellow Alert for heavy rain signifies that future weather conditions could pose a threat. Stay informed by monitoring official news, radio, and weather updates. Be aware of the potential for flooding.

Alert Level 2 (Amber - Be Prepared): An Amber Alert indicates that heavy rain is expected and flooding is likely. You should prepare to take action. Secure your property, pack an emergency go-bag, and be ready to evacuate if conditions worsen.

Alert Level 3 (Red - Take Action): A Red Alert means dangerous, life-threatening weather and widespread flooding are imminent. You must take action now to protect yourself. Follow all evacuation orders from authorities without delay.
Flash Flood Warning: This is the most urgent type of alert. It means a sudden and violent flood is happening or about to happen. Do not wait for instructions. Move to higher ground immediately.

Alert Dissemination Protocol: Warnings are sent out through multiple channels to ensure wide reach. This includes national TV and radio broadcasts, SMS alerts, social media posts by official agencies, and via community loudspeaker systems.

Alert Trigger (Rainfall): Weather alerts are based on specific rainfall forecasts. For example, an Amber alert might be issued when over 100mm of rain is forecast in 24 hours, and a Red alert when over 150mm is forecast.

Responder Protocol (Amber Alert): When an Amber Alert is issued, all response teams must be on standby. This includes checking equipment, fueling vehicles and boats, reviewing rosters, and preparing for potential deployment.

Alert Cancellation: Do not return to evacuated areas until an official 'All Clear' or cancellation of the weather warning has been announced by the authorities. The risk may continue even after the rain stops.

Public Action for Red Alert: When a Red Alert is active, your life is in danger. If you are in a risk area, you must evacuate. Go to an official shelter or the home of friends/family on higher ground. Do not stay behind.

Issuing Authority: A mandatory evacuation order is a legal directive that can only be issued by a designated government authority, such as a District Secretary or the Director General of the NDMC. The order must be formally documented.

Registry Data (Required): Every evacuation order must be logged in a central registry. The entry must include a unique ID, the issuing authority, date/time, type (Voluntary/Mandatory), a precise geographic area, and the current status (Active/Lifted).

Registry Data (Geography): The area under an evacuation order must be defined with a map polygon and a clear list of all affected administrative boundaries (e.g., Grama Niladhari divisions). Vague descriptions are operationally useless.

Dissemination Protocol: Once an order is logged in the registry, it must be immediately broadcast to the public via all available channels, including SMS, radio, television, and through police or military personnel on the ground.

Registry Status ('Active'): When an order's status is 'Active' in the registry, it means the area is a no-go zone for all unauthorized persons. This is enforced by law enforcement to ensure public safety and allow unhindered rescue operations.

Registry Update (Clearance): After an order is issued, response teams must sweep the area to ensure all residents have left. Once a zone is confirmed empty, its status in the registry should be updated to 'Active - Cleared'.

Lifting Protocol: The authority who issued the evacuation order is responsible for lifting it. The decision must be based on a formal safety assessment and must be recorded in the registry with the date and time it is lifted.

Coordination Protocol: The evacuation orders registry is the single source of truth for all responding agencies. It must be consulted before deploying teams or planning logistics to know which areas are restricted.

Order Types: The registry must clearly differentiate between 'Voluntary Evacuation Advisory' (high risk, residents strongly urged to leave) and 'Mandatory Evacuation Order' (imminent threat, residents legally required to leave).

Re-entry Communication: When an evacuation order's status is changed to 'Lifted' in the registry, a corresponding 'All Clear' message is sent to the public, advising them that it is now safe to return to the area.

Step 1 (All Documents): To replace any official document lost in the flood, your first step is to obtain a letter from your Grama Niladhari (GN). This letter certifies your address and the loss of documents due to the disaster.

Step 2 (All Documents): With the letter from your Grama Niladhari, go to the nearest police station to file a report. You will need a copy of this police report for almost all document replacement applications.

Government Assistance: Look for announcements about special 'Mobile Service' events in your area. These one-stop-shops are organized by the government to help flood victims apply for multiple lost documents (like IDs and birth certificates) at one location.

National ID Card (NIC) Replacement: To apply for a new NIC, submit the GN letter, police report, and a copy of your birth certificate (if you have one) to the special counter at your Divisional Secretariat. Photographs may be taken on-site.

Birth Certificate Replacement: To get a new copy of a birth, marriage, or death certificate, you can apply at your Divisional Secretariat. Provide the police report and as many details as you can, such as full names and date of birth.

Public Information (Fees): For declared disasters, the government may waive the usual fees for replacing essential documents. Confirm at the application point if the 'disaster victim' fee waiver is in effect.

Driving License Replacement: To replace a lost driver's license, you will need the police report and your NIC number. Applications are processed by the Department of Motor Traffic (DMT), which may set up special counters for flood victims.

Preparedness Tip: To make future recovery easier, keep digital copies of important documents like your NIC, passport, and birth certificate. You can save them in your email or a secure cloud storage service.

Humanitarian Support: Aid organizations like the Red Cross and other NGOs may run legal aid clinics in shelters or community centers. They can offer free advice and assistance with filling out the necessary forms to replace your documents.

Land Title Replacement: Replacing a lost or damaged land deed is a legal process. Start by getting a police report and GN letter. Then, you must apply for a certified copy from the Land Registry. It is highly recommended to consult a lawyer or a legal aid service.

Step 1 (All Claims): As soon as it is safe, take detailed photographs and videos of the damage to your home, business, and belongings. This visual evidence is extremely important for both insurance claims and government compensation applications.

Government Compensation (Damage Assessment): Wait for official damage assessment teams from the Divisional Secretariat and your Grama Niladhari (GN) to visit your area. Ensure you are present to show them the damage to your property.

Government Compensation (Documentation): After the official assessment, you must obtain a 'Damage Certificate' from your Grama Niladhari. This document is the official proof of your losses and is required to be submitted for the government compensation scheme.

Private Insurance Claims: If your property is insured against floods, contact your insurance company immediately to initiate a claim. They will provide you with a claim number and schedule a visit from an insurance assessor.

Compensation Framework: Government compensation for damaged houses is typically based on two tiers: 'Fully Damaged' and 'Partially Damaged'. The financial amount for each tier is determined by national policy and the official damage assessment.

Fraud Warning: Be cautious of scams. Official government assessors and aid workers will never ask you for money to file a claim or receive compensation. Report anyone demanding payment to the police immediately.

Insurance Tip: Do not discard damaged items or make permanent repairs before the insurance assessor has inspected your property. You can make temporary repairs to prevent further damage, like covering a hole in the roof.

Livelihood Compensation: If your livelihood was affected (e.g., loss of crops, livestock, or business equipment), report this separately to the assessment team. Specific government departments handle these types of claims.

Clarification of Roles: Humanitarian agencies like the UN and Red Cross focus on providing immediate life-saving aid (food, water, shelter). They do not typically provide financial compensation for property damage; this is a government responsibility.

Public Information: Government compensation is intended to help with basic recovery and rebuilding of primary homes. It is not intended to replace all lost items and generally does not cover vehicles or luxury goods.
Public Guidance: If it is not safe for you, it is not safe for your pets. If you are ordered to evacuate, take your pets with you. Never leave them chained or caged to drown.

Livestock Evacuation: Well before floodwaters rise, all livestock owners in at-risk areas should move their animals (cattle, goats, poultry) to pre-identified high ground with access to food and clean water.

Responder Protocol: The primary mandate of search and rescue teams is to save human life. Animal rescue will only be attempted when all human life in the area is safe and the rescue does not pose a risk to the team.

Pet Preparedness: Prepare a 'go-bag' for your pet that includes a 3-day supply of food and water, any medications, a leash and collar or carrier, and copies of vaccination records in a waterproof bag.

Shelter Information: Not all public shelters can accommodate pets due to health and safety regulations. Please check with the Disaster Management Centre for a list of pet-friendly shelters or temporary animal shelters in your district.

Temporary Animal Shelters: Coordinate with the Department of Animal Health and local veterinary NGOs to establish temporary animal shelters in safe locations for housing rescued and evacuated animals.

Identification Protocol: Make sure your pet wears a collar with an ID tag containing your phone number. For rescued animals, responders should photograph the animal and record the rescue location to assist with reunification.

Public Health Protocol: The proper disposal of animal carcasses after a flood is a critical public health priority to prevent the spread of disease. This task must be handled by trained government veterinary or public health teams.

Safety Warning: Approach animals in floodwaters with caution. They are likely to be frightened, possibly injured, and may act aggressively to defend themselves. Do not attempt to handle unfamiliar or wild animals.

Coordination Protocol: The District Disaster Management Coordination Committee must include a representative from the Department of Animal Production and Health to coordinate all aspects of livestock evacuation and animal welfare.

Triage Setup: A dedicated veterinary triage area must be established at any temporary animal shelter. It should be located at the entrance, be secure, and have separate, clearly marked zones for each triage category (Red, Yellow, Green) to prevent injury and disease spread.

Triage Category (Red - Immediate): Red-tagged animals have critical, life-threatening injuries (e.g., severe bleeding, shock, respiratory distress) but a good prognosis with immediate veterinary intervention. They are the top priority for treatment.

Triage Category (Yellow - Delayed): Yellow-tagged animals have serious injuries (e.g., open fractures, deep wounds) that are not immediately life-threatening. They require treatment but can wait until all Red-tagged animals have been stabilized.

Triage Category (Green - Minor): Green-tagged animals, the 'walking wounded,' have minor injuries like superficial cuts or mild dehydration. They should be moved to a separate holding area to await treatment after more serious cases are handled.

Triage Category (Black - Deceased/Expectant): Black-tagged animals are either deceased or have injuries so severe that survival is not possible. To prevent suffering, humane euthanasia by a qualified vet is the recommended course of action for expectant cases.

Public Health Screening: During triage, a veterinarian must assess every animal for signs of zoonotic diseases (e.g., rabies). Any animal showing suspicious symptoms must be immediately isolated and reported to public health authorities.

Personnel Protocol: Veterinary triage must only be conducted by, or under the direct supervision of, qualified veterinarians or veterinary paraprofessionals. First responders should focus on safe capture and transport, not diagnosis.

Documentation Protocol: Every animal must receive a waterproof triage tag indicating its unique ID, triage color, species, location found, and a brief summary of its injuries. This is essential for tracking treatment and outcomes.

Public Guidance: 'If you find an injured animal, please do not move it unless it's in immediate danger. Approach with caution. Report the location and type of animal to the official animal rescue hotline at [Hotline Number].'

Triage Consideration (Livestock): For livestock, triage decisions may also involve economic factors. In consultation with veterinary authorities, animals with severe injuries but which are still fit for consumption may be prioritized for humane slaughter.

Shelter Option 1 (Co-located): A 'co-located' shelter is a human evacuation center that has a separate, designated space on the same property to house pets. This is a preferred option as it allows owners to remain close to their animals.

Shelter Option 2 (Standalone): A 'standalone' emergency animal shelter is a temporary facility established solely for animal care. It should be located in a flood-safe area and have adequate space, security, ventilation, and access to clean water.

Livestock Shelter Option: For large animals like cattle and goats, designate secure, high-ground open areas as temporary shelters. Locations like school grounds or community parks can be used if they are safely fenced and have access to water and fodder.

Public Information Template: 'A temporary animal shelter has been set up at [Location and Address]. If you must evacuate and cannot take your pets, you may bring them here for safety. Please provide a leash/carrier and any special food or medication.'

Shelter Intake Protocol: Upon arrival, every animal must be registered. The intake form should include the owner's name and contact info, a photo of the pet, and notes on medical conditions. The animal must be given a unique ID collar.

Hygiene and Disease Control Protocol: Kennels and enclosures must be cleaned and disinfected daily. Any animal showing signs of infectious disease must be immediately isolated from the general population and seen by a veterinarian.

Shelter Alternative (Foster Care): Activate a pre-screened network of volunteer foster homes to provide temporary care for evacuated pets. This is especially beneficial for animals that do not cope well in a crowded shelter environment.

Staffing Protocol: An emergency animal shelter should be run by a qualified manager with animal handling experience. Key roles include intake registration, feeding and cleaning crews, and a veterinary liaison for medical issues.

Reunification Protocol: The primary goal is reunification. Maintain a visible photo board of all sheltered animals at the site and, if possible, a corresponding online photo album to help owners find their lost pets.

Shelter Option 3 (Co-habitated): A 'co-habitated' shelter allows owners to keep crated pets next to them in the main sleeping area. This option has significant space and hygiene challenges and is only suitable for certain buildings and situations.

MHPSS Level 1 (Psychological First Aid): All responders should be trained in Psychological First Aid (PFA). The goal is to provide a humane, supportive response to people in distress. Listen without pressing for details, provide practical comfort, and help them feel safe.

Referral Trigger: A referral to a higher level of mental health care is needed if a person shows signs of severe distress that do not lessen over time, is unable to manage basic daily tasks, or expresses thoughts of harming themselves or others.

MHPSS Level 2 (Community Support): For those with ongoing but mild distress, refer them to community-based support. This includes activities in 'safe spaces' at shelters, peer support groups, and trained psychosocial volunteers.

MHPSS Level 3 (Professional Counselling): Individuals with severe and persistent psychological reactions should be referred to a qualified mental health professional (e.g., counselor, psychologist) for focused, non-specialized support. This referral must be confidential.

MHPSS Level 4 (Specialized Care): Urgent referral to psychiatric services is required for anyone who is a danger to themselves or others, or has a pre-existing severe mental health condition that has been exacerbated by the flood.

Confidentiality Protocol: All mental health referrals are strictly confidential. Obtain informed consent before sharing any information. A person's mental health status must be protected and respected at all times.

Public Information Template: 'It is normal to feel stressed or overwhelmed after a disaster. Talking can help. Confidential support is available from trained volunteers at all major evacuation centers. You are not alone.'

Child MHPSS Referral: Children showing prolonged signs of distress (like nightmares, withdrawal, or aggression) should be guided to a Child-Friendly Space. The trained staff there can provide support and determine if a specialized referral is needed.

Referral Pathway Mapping: The Health Cluster must develop and share a '4Ws' map (Who does What, Where, for Whom) of all available MHPSS services. This map is an essential tool for all responders to make appropriate referrals.

Continuity of Care: A key priority is to identify people who were already receiving mental health treatment before the flood. The referral pathway must include a process to help them reconnect with their service providers and get their medications.

Escalation Step 1 (Immediate Safety): If you suspect someone is at immediate risk of suicide, the most important action is to NOT leave them alone. Stay with them or ensure a trusted person stays with them until professional help arrives.

Escalation Step 2 (Ask Directly): It is vital to ask the person directly about suicide. A question like, 'Are you thinking about ending your life?' will not give them the idea, but it opens the door for them to talk about it and for you to help.

Escalation Step 3 (Contact Specialist): Immediately escalate the situation to your team leader and the designated MHPSS (Mental Health and Psychosocial Support) focal point. Use your radio or phone to clearly state you have a critical MHPSS case.

Safety Step (Remove Means): While talking to the person, calmly remove any obvious means of self-harm from their immediate surroundings if it is safe to do so. This includes items like knives, ropes, pills, or chemicals.

Communication Protocol: Listen to their story with empathy and without judgment. Do not argue or debate their feelings. Acknowledge their pain by saying things like, 'I hear how much pain you are in.' This helps to build trust.

Ethical Guideline: You must NOT promise to keep their suicidal thoughts a secret. Gently explain that because you are worried for their safety, you need to get them more help. Your priority is to keep them alive.

Referral Protocol: The MHPSS focal point will guide the formal referral. This involves safely connecting the individual with a trained health professional or transporting them to the nearest medical facility with psychiatric services for an expert assessment.

Public Information (Hotline): 'Feeling hopeless after a disaster is understandable. If you are in distress or having thoughts of suicide, please know that help is available and you are not alone. Call the National Mental Health Hotline at 1926 any time.'

Volunteer Guideline: If you are a general volunteer and you encounter someone at risk, your role is to 1) Stay with them, and 2) Immediately find and alert your team leader or a staff member from a lead agency. Do not try to manage the situation alone.

Responder Support: Any responder who is involved in a suicide intervention must attend a mandatory critical incident debriefing. This is to ensure the responder's own mental wellbeing is supported after a highly stressful event.

GIS for Shelters: The operational map must display all official shelters, color-coded by status (Green: Open, Yellow: Nearing Capacity, Red: Full). This allows operators to direct incoming evacuees to the nearest available shelter.

GIS for Hospitals: The hospital map layer must show the location and operational status (e.g., Functional, Damaged, Inaccessible) of all medical facilities. This is critical for ambulance dispatch to route patients to a capable and accessible hospital.

GIS for Routes: All rescue teams must use the official GIS map for navigation. It overlays impassable/flooded roads on the base map, allowing for dynamic planning of the safest and quickest routes for boats and emergency vehicles.

GIS for Hazards: The map must include specific hazard layers. This includes pre-identified landslide risk zones and the locations of major industrial sites where chemical spills could occur. This helps in proactive monitoring and issuing targeted warnings.

GIS Analysis (Isolation): Use GIS analysis to identify communities that are cut off. By overlaying the flood inundation layer with the road network, you can pinpoint villages with no safe access routes, prioritizing them for air or boat operations.
Public Map Information: 'A map of all open evacuation shelters is available on the district website. You can see the address and current status. Go to the nearest GREEN (open) shelter on the map.'

GIS for Search and Rescue (SAR): The affected area on the map should be divided into a grid. SAR teams are assigned specific grid squares to search systematically. This ensures full coverage and prevents teams from searching the same area twice.

GIS for Safety (No-Go Zones): Maintain a real-time 'No-Go Zone' layer on all responder maps. This layer highlights extreme hazards like downed power lines, chemical spills, or collapsing structures where entry is forbidden without specialist approval.

GIS for Damage Assessment: Field teams should use a mobile GIS application to record the location and damage level of each affected house. This data automatically populates a damage map, which is essential for planning compensation and recovery efforts.

GIS Analysis (Nearest Facility): From any incident point on the map, the GIS can instantly calculate the route and travel time to the nearest operational hospital, relief supply point, or boat launch, optimizing response time.

Shelter Reporting Protocol: The manager of each official evacuation shelter must report their occupancy numbers to the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) twice a day, at 08:00 and 20:00. This is mandatory for tracking available space.

Shelter Data Feed (Required): The data feed from each shelter must, at a minimum, include: Total Capacity, Current Occupancy, and Number of Available Spaces. Where possible, this data should be disaggregated by age and gender.

Hospital Reporting Protocol: All hospitals in the affected region must report their capacity status to the Health Cluster or Ministry of Health every four hours. This high frequency is critical for managing patient transfers during a crisis.

Hospital Data Feed (Required): The hospital capacity feed must specify the number of available beds in the Emergency Room, general wards, and the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). It must also state the status of the operating theater (Open/Closed).

Data Integration Protocol: All incoming capacity reports from shelters and hospitals must be fed into a centralized, live dashboard in the EOC. This provides a single common operational picture for all decision-makers.

Operational Use (Hospitals): Dispatchers MUST use the live capacity feed to route ambulances. If a hospital's feed shows its ER is 'On Divert' or 'Full,' ambulances must be directed to the next nearest appropriate facility with available capacity.

Operational Use (Shelters): Once a shelter's capacity feed indicates it is over 90% full, field teams and public announcements must redirect new evacuees to alternative shelters that have confirmed available space.

Public Information Template: 'NOTICE: The evacuation shelter at [Shelter Name] is now at full capacity. Please do not proceed to this location. The nearest shelter with available space is at [Alternate Shelter Name and Address].'

Data Verification Protocol: To ensure data accuracy, Information Management Officers at the EOC should make random verification calls to a sample of shelters and hospitals each day to confirm the numbers reported in the automated feed.

Shelter Data Collection: The primary method for tracking shelter occupancy is the registration desk at the entrance. The total number of registered individuals is the basis for the capacity report. A manual headcount should be done daily to verify.

Reporting Frequency: All designated hospitals must update their bed occupancy feed to the Health Emergency Operations Center (EOC) every four hours. During a mass casualty surge, the reporting frequency may be increased to hourly.

Data Point (ER Status): A critical field in the feed is the Emergency Room (ER) status, using standard codes: 'Open' (accepting all patients), 'On Divert' (accepting only critical trauma/cardiac), or 'Closed' (accepting no new ambulance traffic).

Data Point (ICU Beds): The feed must provide a discrete count of available, staffed Intensive Care Unit (ICU) beds. This number is the primary deciding factor for routing critically ill patients requiring life support.

Data Point (General Ward Beds): The number of available beds in general medical and surgical wards must be reported. This helps the EOC plan for transfers of stable patients out of the ER and from other overwhelmed hospitals.

Data Point (Specialty Services): The occupancy feed must also report the status of critical specialty services. For a flood, this includes the availability of operating theaters for surgery and the status of pediatric and maternity wards.

Operational Use (Load Balancing): The central medical dispatch unit uses the combined occupancy feed from all hospitals to perform 'patient load balancing,' distributing incoming casualties across multiple facilities to prevent any single hospital from being overwhelmed.

Data Flow Protocol: The hospital's designated incident manager or chief administrator is responsible for ensuring the accuracy of the bed count data and its timely transmission to the Health EOC via the agreed-upon platform (e.g., web portal, API).

Data Point (Ventilators): Given the risk of near-drowning incidents in a flood, the number of available, functional mechanical ventilators is a specific and critical data point that must be included in the feed from all ICU-capable hospitals.

Public Communication Use: While exact bed numbers are confidential, the occupancy feed informs public messaging. A message may be: 'Hospitals in the Colombo district are extremely busy due to the floods. Please reserve the Emergency Room for life-threatening injuries only.'

Data Point (Surge Status): The feed should include a field indicating if the hospital has activated its internal surge capacity plan. This context helps the EOC understand the level of stress on the hospital's resources and staff.

Reporting Protocol: The designated manager of each evacuation shelter is responsible for submitting an occupancy report to the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) twice daily, typically at 08:00 and 20:00, using the provided form or app.

Data Point (Capacity vs. Occupancy): The feed must clearly state the shelter's total planned capacity and the current number of individuals occupying it. This calculation (Occupancy/Capacity) determines the percentage full, a critical metric for planning.

Data Point (Disaggregation): Occupancy data must be disaggregated by Sex, Age, and Disability (SADD). This is essential for understanding the demographic profile of the shelter and identifying the specific needs of vulnerable groups.

Data Point (Household Count): The feed should also report the total number of distinct families or households. This data point is crucial for planning the distribution of family-sized food and non-food item kits.

Data Collection Method: Occupancy numbers are primarily derived from the registration forms completed by evacuees upon arrival. A physical headcount should be conducted each evening to verify the registered numbers.

Operational Use: When the occupancy feed shows a shelter is nearing its capacity (e.g., 90% full), the EOC must issue an advisory to all field teams and broadcast to the public to divert new evacuees to an alternative shelter.

Public Information Template: 'The evacuation shelter at the Piliyandala Central College is now full. The nearest available shelter is at the Kesbewa Urban Council Hall. Please proceed to the new location.'

Data Visualization: On the EOC's central dashboard, all shelter locations should be color-coded based on their occupancy feed: Green for below 75% full, Yellow for 75-95% full, and Red for over 95% full or at capacity.

Data Point (New Arrivals): The feed should include a count of new arrivals since the previous report. This helps planners at the EOC understand the rate of displacement and anticipate future needs for shelter space and resources.

Data Verification: Information Management Officers at the EOC are responsible for the quality of the feed. They should conduct periodic phone calls to shelter managers to confirm the accuracy of the reported occupancy numbers.
